{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3362889,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T18:18:05.272Z","cooked":"

As we are approaching the off season, just as the majority of teams out there are, we are considering off season changes we would like to do to “improve” our 2024 robot for off season competitions.
One of our ideas will include adding a shooter powered by Falcon 500s. All other motors on our robot are run buy SparkMax controllers (Rev SwereMax and a few Neo 550s).
We have been told by a couple local teams that mixing SparkMax and Falcons on the same CAN bus is a bad idea. Now, no one has given any hard evidence of the issues, or root cause of why this is a bad idea, but it has all been anecdotal.
Searching on CD has not revealed any specifics on this subject, thus this post.
Can anyone point us to factual information on this subject? We are looking for solid information so we can either find a way to use but controller types on the same robot, or avoid it completely.
It was suggested by one team to just use a CANivore for the Falcon bus, but that is a ~$300 addition cost we really don’t have to spare right now.
Any solid info would be greatly appreciated.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T18:23:31.516Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":46,"reads":290,"readers_count":289,"score":288.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"billbo911","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://store.ctr-electronics.com/canivore/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CANivore","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/1","custom_user_title":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3362895,"name":"Michelle Banas","username":"Notquitebananas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/notquitebananas/{size}/255355_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T18:24:07.059Z","cooked":"

Anecdotal: I’ve seen it work just fine it’s just kind of annoying to have to switch between hardware clients when setting things up. More of an inconvenience than anything.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T18:24:07.059Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":264,"readers_count":263,"score":82.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Michelle Banas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65540,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RI, CSA, FTAA | 2403M/3062A"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/2","custom_user_title":"RI, CSA, FTAA | 2403M/3062A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3362896,"name":"Ken Pontbriant","username":"electroken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/electroken/{size}/160387_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T18:24:18.417Z","cooked":"

We have 14 Falcons and 1 SparkMax on our single CAN bus. While we’ve had our share of problems this year, that wasn’t one of them. They seem to play together just fine.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T18:28:50.497Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":256,"readers_count":255,"score":91.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Ken Pontbriant","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17612,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 230 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/3","custom_user_title":"FRC 230 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3362903,"name":"Cody B.","username":"Heckboy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T18:35:46.853Z","cooked":"

The only conflict that should arise is the potential for mismatched CAN ID’s (i.e. a SparkMax being ID4 on the REV Hardware Client, and a Falcon also being ID4 on the Phoenix Tuner). It shouldn’t be too much of an issue as long as you keep things organized, and program them in a way that makes sense (not having the Falcon ID’s be sandwiched between the SparkMax ID’s. Doing something like SparkMax ID’s being 1-8 and Falcon ID’s being like 9-13 should work fine). Realistically, as long as things are wired correctly, and ID’s are assigned properly within their respective clients, then its no different than having multiple things on a CAN bus like you normally would.

One thing they could be referring to is the inability to edit Rev products on Phoenix Tuner, and vise versa. So much so, that the products don’t even register on the different clients. Just make sure you have both the REV Hardware Client, and Phoenix Tuner downloaded, and you should be all good.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T18:38:04.108Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":73.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Cody B.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50904,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"M&A-904"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/4","custom_user_title":"M&A-904","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3362910,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T18:41:12.628Z","cooked":"

These are exactly the way we would approach this. So, thank you for helping us verify our processes.
I agree, having to use two different apps to configure these motors is inconvenient, but it does help the students to learn to pay attention to details.

This year we used Falcons and CANCoders for our swerve, Talon SRX with different DC motors for our climb, intake pivot, and shooter pivot, and NEO Vortecies for shooter fly wheels and intake wheels.

Our incredibly mixed configuration worked just fine.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T18:52:19.764Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":30.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/6","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3362928,"name":"Ryan Blue","username":"Ryan_Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T19:00:12.878Z","cooked":"
Heckboy:

The only conflict that should arise is the potential for mismatched CAN ID’s (i.e. a SparkMax being ID4 on the REV Hardware Client, and a Falcon also being ID4 on the Phoenix Tuner).

This doesn’t matter- devices of different types/vendors can share IDs. Only devices of the same type from the same vendor need to have unique IDs. You can have a PDP, PCM, TalonFX, and Spark MAX all with the same CAN ID if you wanted, but you can’t have 2 TalonFXs with the same ID.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T19:00:59.625Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":96.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Ryan Blue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29846,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/7","custom_user_title":"WPILib Dev | 1024 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3362936,"name":"Cody B.","username":"Heckboy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/da6949/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T19:06:05.273Z","cooked":"

Really?? That’s actually kinda shocking to hear. I did not know that.

Granted, I still think it would be a good practice to make sure that they all have different ID’s regardless of vendor. Mostly for organizational purposes.

Two houses on different streets can have the same house number

There was an issue with the Spark Flex (the newer controller for the Vortex) that was fixed in an early-season update:

docs.revrobotics.com

SPARK Flex Firmware Changelog | REV ION Brushless

Maybe this is what people were referring to?

Whilst you are correct, I still think it would be a good practice to not give a bunch of houses within the same area, the same house number as this could lead to confusion amongst people such as mail workers and they could accidentally deliver the wrong mail to the wrong house

You can even have 2 TalonFXs with the same ID if they are not on the same bus

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2024-04-15T19:55:10.095Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":19.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":462947,"topic_slug":"falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts","display_username":"Ibrahim Ahmad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":29846,"username":"Ryan_Blue","name":"Ryan Blue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_blue/{size}/174016_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53576,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CAN't Bus"},"post_url":"/t/falcon-500-and-sparkmax-on-same-can-bus-conflicts/462947/12","custom_user_title":"CAN't Bus","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3363093,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-15T22:00:44.114Z","cooked":"

My house is a few houses down from a 3-way intersection with 3 different street names. To anonymize it a bit, this isnt my house numher, but lets say my house is 100. Both of the other streets have a 100, and near that intersection (all 3 streets count down as you move away from the intersection). I certainly wouldn’t have designed it that way, but it also hasn’t caused any issues with USPS.

That said, I wouldn’t bother encouraging teams to change CAN IDs to unique ranges based on manufacturer. Not only is it unnecessary (see above comments), but it could also be detrimental. You already have a roborio at ID 1, and a PDP/PDH at ID 1, etc. If you get in the mindset of changing things, teams may want to change their PDH to, say, 11. The problem is the code that collects the PDH metrics (i.e. current draw per port) expects that device to be ID 1. So without it you won’t get any data, and the cause may not be obvious.

ETA: here’s the CAN ID spec that everyone conforms to: FRC CAN Device Specifications — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

Hey Fletch, I believe you posted that same link in a different thread. It REALLY helped us learn a bunch about how the CAN bus operates in this environment. In fact, it is because of this document that I was surprised when I heard from more than one source that there might be conflicts when Rev SparkMax and Vex Falcon 500s coexisted on the same bus.
It literally makes no sense that there would be unless one of the two were not adhereing to this standard. From what has been reported here, there doesn’t actuality appear to be an issue.

You basically never want to change the PDP or PDH CAN ID from their defaults (PDP 0, PDH 1); doing so removes the power logging in the Driver Station. (Note that WPILib does allow robot code to read from different CAN IDs for the PDP/PDH but doing so will still not send it to the DS logs.)

For the PCM and PH, WPILib makes it easy to use the default CAN IDs (PCM 0, PH 1), so it really only makes sense to change their CAN ID if you need multiple.

To keep following your street number analogy…

In Australia all street numbers start from 1. It’s also possible to have 2 different streets within the same city with the same name, and they would both still start counting from 1. A house with the same street name and number are disambiguated by postcode, and any mail will list the suburb as well to allow double-checking the postcode.

It’s really not as confusing as you make it out to be.
